title: Split in the establishment as AFIC dumps AMP
text:
AMP shares have lost 75 per cent of their value over the past four years, and the stock has almost been decimated since peaking in April 2007.

As recently as March 2018 AMP was AFIC's 18th biggest holding, with more than $100 million ( or 1.5 per cent of AFIC's funds) invested in the financial services provider.

Aside from the financial consequences of the selldown, the exit of 91-year-old AFIC from the register of 170-year-old AMP is highly symbolic, as it shows one of the nation's establishment investment houses giving up on Australia's oldest wealth manager and one of the nation's most storied blue chip companies.

New AMP chief executive Francesco De Ferrari has launched a turn around strategy for AMP that involves slashing costs, selling non-core assets and raising $650 million of equity.

Mr Freeman stressed that AFIC was not a fairweather friend, and said he would not rule out returning to the AMP share register in future.

''We understand that many companies go through periods where there are issues facing them, I can't think of many stocks in our portfolio that haven't had some sort of issue that they have had to deal with,'' he said.

''We have seen sectors go through very dark periods before, the view on BHP and Rio Tinto was very low in the period where commodity prices got sold off and we got asked questions about why we are holding them and then things turned around.

''The (AMP) brand still has value, but we have just made a decision at this point to move on. We will keep watching it,'' he said.

"If we get comfort over time that they can re-establish their strength in that sector we would look at it again."

AFIC also exited Perpetual, Incitec Pivot, Clydesdale Bank and shopping mall owner Unibail-Rodamco in the past year.
description: One of Australia's oldest and biggest investment houses has called time on its investment in the nation's oldest wealth manager.
